Key Arguments: The legislation threatens freedom of speech, which is implicit in all democracies.
The Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) will have too much power in deciding what constitutes misinformation and disinformation.
The legislation exempts certain groups, such as professional news content and government bodies, which could lead to biased enforcement.
The proposed powers could be used to silence dissenting voices and enforce government narratives.
There is a risk of political bias in ACMA's decisions, which could undermine democratic processes.
Notable Quotes: 'Think of the press as a great keyboard on which the government can play.'
Having unelected persons within a body (ACMA) decide what is ‘misinformation and disinformation’ is dangerous, considering the probability of political bias.
The list of exemptions excludes those who have the most influence – politicians, bureaucrats and educational institutions – whose main drivers are power and control.
